It‚Äôs been a while since we used one. Wondering if anyone has any recommendations for a good line break sensor.

Thanks in advance

They‚Äôre pricey and you need to pay attention to the datasheet when purchasing/wiring them, but Banner Engineering photoelectic sensors are extremely robust (e.g. Q18VN6LV or similar).

3468 has used these IR Reflective Sensors in the past with really good results, they‚Äôre cheap and simple to mount. I‚Äôve been told you can run into issues with IR light from Venue Lighting causing false triggers, but we‚Äôve not run into that personally.

amazon.com

HiLetgo 3pcs E18-D80NK Infrared Photoelectric Switch Obstacle Avoidance Sensor...

HiLetgo 3pcs E18-D80NK Infrared Photoelectric Switch Obstacle Avoidance Sensor Module: Amazon.com: Industrial & Scientific

This is pretty cool. I will need to read up on how it works. Any additional info about how you made this work on your robot would be appreciated

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2023-01-23T13:50:29.359Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":144,"readers_count":143,"score":43.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":424352,"topic_slug":"line-breaker","display_username":"nuggetsyl","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":16897,"username":"ExploitSage","name":"Mykah","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/exploitsage/{size}/179189_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":261,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/line-breaker/424352/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3132244,"name":"Mykah","username":"ExploitSage","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/exploitsage/{size}/179189_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-23T14:03:10.814Z","cooked":"

They work by having an IR LED and Photoelectric Transistor next to each other. So when enough of the IR Light from the LED reflects off of something close and onto the transistor, it changes the output. The light threshold can be adjusted using a small pot on the side of the housing you can adjust with a screwdriver. It gives a simple digital (on/off or true/false) output like a switch so you can wire it directly to a DIO port on the RIO and access it from a DigitalInput object in WPILib.

We used three of these on our Conveyor Belt subsystem back in 2020 for Infinite Recharge to track the intake and firing of the lemons (balls). Two next to each other on the bottom to help us achieve spacing between the balls so they wouldn‚Äôt rub against each other and jam, and one at the top to know when the conveyor was full, and to queue up the next ball when shooting. Here is how we set them up in our Subsystem to be accessed:

github.com

frc3468/InfiniteRecharge/blob/master/src/main/java/frc/robot/subsystems/Conveyor.java

package frc.robot.subsystems;

import com.revrobotics.CANSparkMax;
import com.revrobotics.CANSparkMaxLowLevel.MotorType;

import edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.DigitalInput;
import edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.smartdashboard.SmartDashboard;
import edu.wpi.first.wpilibj2.command.SubsystemBase;
import frc.robot.Constants.ConveyorConstants;

public class Conveyor extends SubsystemBase {

  private CANSparkMax conveyorMotor;
This file has been truncated. show original

Here is where we used them to control when we triggered the various intake, conveyor, and firing commands to make the actions of intake and firing take only 2 buttons despite having multiple actions:

github.com

frc3468/InfiniteRecharge/blob/04b2cc3525759792e46d09a02245dd7a08b30287/src/main/java/frc/robot/RobotContainer.java#L123-L143


      
    
          
  1. // Internal Robot Triggers
    2. 
          
  2. Trigger initialConveyorDetector = new Trigger(() -> conveyor.getInitialConveyorSensor());
    3. 
          
  3. Trigger finalConveyorDetector = new Trigger(() -> conveyor.getFinalConveyorSensor());
    4. 
          
  4. Trigger launcherConveyorDetector = new Trigger(() -> conveyor.getLauncherConveyorSensor());
    5. 
          
  5. Trigger launcherOnTarget = new Trigger(() -> launcher.isOnTargetAverage(7));
    6. 
          
  6. 
          
    7. 

  7. // Intake
    8. 
          
  8. intakeButton.and(finalConveyorDetector.or(launcherConveyorDetector).negate())
    9. 
          
  9.     .whileActiveContinuous(new IntakeBallIntake(ballIntake));
    10. 
          
  10. 
          
    11. 

  11. // Conveyor
    12. 
          
  12. intakeButton.and(initialConveyorDetector.or(finalConveyorDetector).and(launcherConveyorDetector.negate()))
    13. 
          
  13.     .whileActiveContinuous(new AdvanceConveyor(conveyor));
    14. 
          
  14. 
          
    15. 

  15. // Launcher
    16. 
          
  16. //launchButton.or(setLauncherVelocityOverrideButton).whileActiveContinuous(
    17. 
          
  17. //    new SetLauncherVelocity(launcher, () -> Launcher.distanceToVelocity(camera.getDistanceFromGoal())));
    18. 
          
  18. launchButton.and(launcherOnTarget).whileActiveContinuous(new AdvanceConveyor(conveyor));
    19. 
          
  19. launchButton.and(launcherOnTarget.negate().and(launcherConveyorDetector.negate()))
    20. 
          
  20.     .whileActiveContinuous(new AdvanceConveyor(conveyor));   
    21. 
          
  21. launchButton.whenPressed(new CameraLightOn(camera)).whenReleased(new CameraLightOff(camera));     
    22.
